case_id: Kans Raj v. State of Punjab (2000) 5 SCC 207
facts: Appellant (Kans Raj) married Veena Rani (deceased) on 18.11.1988.
Veena Rani died an unnatural death due to asphyxia resulting from strangulation in her matrimonial home on 20.01.1990.
The death occurred within approximately 1 year and 2 months of the marriage (well within the 7-year period specified in Section 304B IPC).
Prosecution alleged persistent demands for dowry (scooter, fridge, TV) from the appellant and his family.
Father of the deceased (PW1), brother (PW2), and mother (PW3) testified about the dowry demands and harassment meted out to Veena Rani.
PW2 (brother) testified that when he visited Veena about 10-12 days before her death, she complained about harassment for dowry, and the appellant demanded items and threatened dire consequences.
PW1 (father) corroborated the demands and stated Veena was harassed and sometimes beaten.
The appellant was charged under Sections 304B and 498A of the IPC.
The Trial Court convicted the appellant under Sections 304B/34 and 498A/34 IPC.
The High Court upheld the conviction and sentence.
The appellant appealed to the Supreme Court challenging the conviction.
ipc_sections: Section 498A (Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty)
Section 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention - applied by lower courts, less focus in SC appeal on this aspect)
Section 113B Evidence Act (Presumption as to dowry death - Discussed)

prosecution_arguments.argument: All ingredients of Section 304B IPC (Dowry Death) are satisfied.
precedents: State of Punjab v. Iqbal Singh (1991) 3 SCC 1
Shanti v. State of Haryana (1991) 1 SCC 371
Hem Chand v. State of Haryana (1994) 3 SCC 36
elements: Death of a woman occurred otherwise than under normal circumstances (strangulation).
Death occurred within seven years of her marriage.
Soon before her death, she was subjected to cruelty or harassment by her husband or any relative of her husband.
Such cruelty or harassment was for, or in connection with, any demand for dowry.

counter_arguments.loophole: Defense might argue the alleged cruelty was not 'soon before' death, lacking immediate proximity.
supporting_precedents: Sham Lal v. State of Haryana (1997) 9 SCC 759 (Interpreted 'soon before' strictly, though distinguished in Kans Raj)
Surinder Singh v. State of Haryana (2014) 4 SCC 129 (Reiterated need for proximate link)
Rajinder Singh v. State of Punjab (2015) 6 SCC 477 (Elaborated on 'soon before' requiring a live link)

prosecution_arguments.argument: Cruelty as defined under Section 498A IPC is established through consistent witness testimony.
precedents: Girdhar Shankar Tawade v. State of Maharashtra (2002) 5 SCC 177 (Definition and scope of cruelty)
State of Karnataka v. H.S. Srinivasa (2000) 9 SCC 461 (Cruelty linked to dowry demands)
Pawan Kumar v. State of Haryana (1998) 3 SCC 309 (Persistent demands and harassment constitute cruelty)
elements: Willful conduct likely to cause grave injury or danger to life, limb or health (mental or physical).
Harassment of the woman where such harassment is with a view to coercing her or any person related to her to meet any unlawful demand for property or valuable security.

counter_arguments.loophole: Witnesses (PW1, PW2, PW3) are close relatives and thus 'interested witnesses', requiring careful scrutiny and corroboration.
supporting_precedents: M. Narsinga Rao v. State of A.P. (2001) 1 SCC 691 (Caution regarding interested witnesses, but relationship per se not disqualifying)
Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab (1954) SCR 145 (Relationship not a reason to discard testimony if credible)
Sarwan Singh v. State of Punjab (1976) 4 SCC 369 (Need for corroboration depends on facts)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The presumption under Section 113B of the Indian Evidence Act is applicable and unrebutted.
precedents: Hem Chand v. State of Haryana (1994) 3 SCC 36
State of Punjab v. Iqbal Singh (1991) 3 SCC 1
State of West Bengal v. Orilal Jaiswal (1994) 1 SCC 73 (Nature of presumption and burden of proof)
elements: Showing that 'soon before her death' the woman was subjected by the accused to cruelty or harassment.
Such cruelty or harassment was for, or in connection with, any demand for dowry.
Once proven, the court 'shall presume' that the accused caused the dowry death.

counter_arguments.loophole: The presumption is rebuttable; defense could attempt to show death was accidental or suicidal (though difficult with strangulation) or that cruelty was unrelated to dowry or not proximate.
supporting_precedents: Ashok Kumar v. State of Haryana (2010) 12 SCC 350 (Presumption is rebuttable)
Baijnath v. State of M.P. (2017) 1 SCC 101 (Distinction between presumption under 113B and proof required for 302 IPC)
Sher Singh @ Partapa v. State of Haryana (2015) 3 SCC 369 (Discussion on rebuttal evidence)

defense_arguments.argument: The prosecution failed to establish a proximate and live link between the alleged harassment and the death; the term 'soon before' under Section 304B IPC is not met.
edge_cases: Interpretation of 'soon before death' - whether a gap of 10-12 days between last reported specific incident (PW2 visit) and death breaks the proximity.
Whether general allegations of past harassment suffice without specific proximate acts.
precedents: Sham Lal v. State of Haryana (1997) 9 SCC 759 (Emphasized proximity, although distinguished later)
Major Singh v. State of Punjab (2015) 5 SCC 201 (Necessity of establishing a proximate link)
Tarsem Singh v. State of Punjab (2008) 16 SCC 155 (Need for credible evidence of proximate cruelty)

defense_arguments.argument: The testimonies of the deceased's relatives (PW1, PW2, PW3) are biased, exaggerated, and lack independent corroboration, making them unreliable.
edge_cases: Admissibility and weightage of testimony from 'interested witnesses' in matrimonial disputes.
Absence of complaints to police or other authorities prior to death.
precedents: M. Narsinga Rao v. State of A.P. (2001) 1 SCC 691 (Requirement of careful scrutiny for interested witnesses)
Kali Ram v. State of Himachal Pradesh (1973) 2 SCC 808 (Burden of proof squarely on prosecution)
Suraj Mal v. State (Delhi Administration) (1979) 4 SCC 725 (Importance of independent corroboration where available)

defense_arguments.argument: No direct evidence connects the appellant to the act of strangulation; conviction based solely on presumption under Section 113B is unsafe without corroborative factors.
edge_cases: Reliance on circumstantial evidence and statutory presumption in the absence of eyewitnesses.
Distinction between causing dowry death (Section 304B) and committing murder (Section 302).
precedents: State of Assam v. Mafizuddin Ahmed (1983) 2 SCC 14 (Principles of circumstantial evidence)
Sharad Birdhichand Sarda v. State of Maharashtra (1984) 4 SCC 116 (Chain of circumstances must be complete)
Baijnath v. State of M.P. (2017) 1 SCC 101 (Section 113B presumption does not automatically prove murder under 302)

judgment.outcome: Appeal Dismissed. Conviction under Sections 304B and 498A IPC upheld.
reasoning: The death, established as unnatural (strangulation), occurred within 1 year 2 months of marriage, satisfying two primary conditions of Section 304B.

The testimonies of PW1, PW2, and PW3 regarding persistent dowry demands and harassment were found credible, consistent, and reliable. Being relatives does not automatically discredit their testimony in such cases.

The term 'soon before' death under Section 304B does not imply 'immediately before'. It requires a proximate and live link between the effect of cruelty based on dowry demand and the death. The continuous harassment and demands, including those mentioned by PW2 10-12 days before the death, established this live link.
The court explicitly distinguished the case from *Sham Lal v. State of Haryana*, noting that here the harassment was persistent and proximate.
Once dowry-related cruelty soon before death was established, the presumption under Section 113B of the Evidence Act became operational.
The defense failed to rebut the statutory presumption under Section 113B.
The evidence clearly established cruelty as defined under Section 498A IPC, linked to unlawful dowry demands.
The High Court and Trial Court correctly appreciated the evidence and applied the law.
